DR. WOOD MAKES
NOVEL RESEARCH
Investigates Properties of High
Frequency Sound Waves
NOT A NEW "DEATH RAY"
But Sound Waves Cause Death of
Fish, Frogs.and Mice
Dr. R. W. Wood, professor of
Physics at Hopkins, has recently
been engaged in important experiments in sound waves of high frequency and great _intensity, generated in an oil-bath by a quartz oscillator operating at 50,000 volts and
Vibrating 300,000, times per second.
These sound waves have produced
very surprising and remarkable effects, the truth of which has been
considerably twisted by reports. A
newspaper scrap mentions Dr.
Wood as having. invented a new
'death ray." This mistake may
have had its origin in the fact that
these high-frequency sound waves
kill fish, frogs and mice when these
creatures are exposed to them for a
sufficient length of time.

WILLIAM AND MARY
Hopkins Will Run Against Weak
Virginia Team Today At
Williamsburg, Va.
William and Mary will be met
by the Johns Hopkins harriers this
afternoon at Williamsburg, Va. As
the William and Mary team is

Jay runners are not expected to

MILITARY ORDER
TO INITIATE FIVE
Five men received the red,
white and blue pledge ribbon
of the Scabbard and Blade,
honorary military fraternity,
last week. They were: J.
Wallace Joyce, unit adjutant;
Ferdinand C. Schmiedicke,
captain company D; Norman
B. Gardiner, Jr., captain company C; Robert A. Reiter,
first lieutenant compay D;
and William E Wyatt, Jr.,
second lieutenant company B.
The new men will be initiated at a Scabbard and Blade
banquet to be held at the Johns
Hopkins Club on Monday
night.

Men Left Yesterday

The Hopkins men left yesterday
morning and after a five hour ride
arrived at Williamsburg last night.
The team left yesterday to avoid
taking a long and fatiguing ride on
the day of the match, Ridgely Edwards, track coach, said. Edwards
accompanied the team.
Due to the length and expense
of the trip only seven Hopkins men
are entered in the race. They are
Captain Herman Schiebel, Gwinn,
Kelley, Wheeler, Emerson, Waters
and Rosser. The team will remain
away over tomorrow in order to
see a football game at Norfolk, returning at night by boat.

JOHN SMITH ISN'T ALWAYS TO BE CONSIDERED
After all, the best of us will get our principles mixed occasionally. We see that our worthy contemporary, the Evening
Sun, laments the absence of "intellectual freedom" at the University of West Virginia. Now this wail, we believe, is a most
noble one, and one that should be wailed whenever such stupidity
as was exercised at West Virginia is demonstrated. On the other
hand, however, the president of the university offered an excuse
which could easily find validity in many of the underlying arguments of Evening Sun editorials.
President Trotter said that the reason why a certain pacifist was
not allowed to speak at West Virginia was that "this is a Statesupported institution and too much turmoil had been caused by
the invitation." Or, in other words, West Virginia is John.
Smith, taxpayer's college, and if John Smith doesn't want some
one to talk at his college, that some one isn't going to talk—that's
all there is to it!
The former principle, it seems to us, is.the more commendable
of the two; intellectual freedom is a higher ideal than a slim tax
rate. Or, perhaps, this is one occasion upon which John Smith
pays his money and then has nothing more to say about it!.

THE NAVY IS RIGHT
It seems pre-eminently ludicrous to us that Yale should bar
Bruce Caldwell from her football team because of participation
in two games during his freshman year at Brown, and expect
Princeton to do the same thing under similar circumstances, when
the United States Military Academy plays bona fide games with
all the leading colleges of the country with men in her line-up
playing their seventh year of college football. If Princeton or
Dartmouth were to use men who were playing their fourth year
of football, Yale should probably protest vehemently; nevertheless,
the Army game is one of the high spots of the Eli schedule every
year.
We cannot blame the Navy for kicking. Why should Navy
have to develop her material each year and go into the biggest
game of the season against men who had been picked on AllAmerican teams before members of the Navy team were out of
high school? It is true that "Biff" 'Jones, the Army coach,
strongly denies trying to convince star football players of the
pleasures and amenities of the great Army life, but it does seem
a little more than a coincidence that the bulwarks of the West
Point elevens for the past few years have been former stars at
other colleges.
The fault lies as much with the large colleges who comprise
the Army schedule as it does with the Army herself. If Yale
and Notre Dame and Bucknell would insist upon Army's barring
men who have already had one football career, Army would have
to fall into line. The Navy, acting alone, seems powerless to cause
any change. It would be, indeed, deplorable if one of the most
colorful annual football classics should be discontinued because
one of the teams insisted upon adhering to an eligibility code that
differed from that of every college in the country.

There is a delightful bit of verse, possessed of that brand of
inanity essential to the immortality of a nursery-rhyme, which—
perhaps because of the insidious influence of the recent red-hot
issue of the Black and Blue Jay—occurs to me whenever some
proud or disconsolate "brother" tells me how many men his fraternity "got." It is a rhyme which the less callous readers will,
in a spirit of unavowed sentiment, associate with that time when
their toes were as tender,as their souls:
This little pig went to market,
This little pig stayed home.
This little pig had roast beef,
This little pig had none.
This little pig said "boo-hoo-hoo!" all the way home.
Some time, when no one is watching, rehearse it—big toe, next
toe, etc. Then apply it to five freshmen, substituting a name—
of course—for each pig. Thus;
This little(?) went Beta,
This little (pain?) stayed home.
This little (lion) had eight bids,
This (poor mutt) had none.
And the last line may be repeated in its original form.
Why an essay on the mysteries of fraternity-rushing should
require all the equipment of a pastoral is an open question. However, the next simile—a worse one, I warn you, than the first—is
also of the barnyard variety. It is concerned with the mysteries
relevant to the separation of the sheep and the goats. Of course,
we have goats on the left hand and sheep on the right, but how
do they get there? It is a matter of everlasting mystery, to one
unendowed with divine powers of selection, that the potential
fraternity men of each ensuing freshman class are apparently
automatically distinguished from those who are (also inexplicably) not eligible. Is it by common consent of the recording
angels who have observed the lives of these poor miserable offenders that A should be sought by all fraternities—and the Buccaneers—while B goes home unpledged, unhonored and unsung?
Or are these cattle easily judged—by the fleece, by the pound, by
the teeth? Sheep and goats. You to the left; you to the right;
you get a bid; you get left. The fallacy in this simile lies in the
author's ignorance of which is which; is the lucky freshman led
like a sheep to slaughter—or is he the goat? It has always been
my intention to ask some sobered and sensible fraternity man,
in an upper class, to which species he belonged, but the dangerous
possibility of his being of a third—and long-eared—family, has
invariably prevented my inquiry. However (here again the likeness is stretched to the breaking point, or beyond), the cattle are
rustled, lassoed, bound by a thousand threats, promises, and suggestions, and eventually each is branded with a Greek letter; Hester Prynne got much the same treatment when she won her "A."
The first little pig, he of the market trip, in all probability put
up a stall—not in the market, but before he got there—and after
he went to market he thought how much better he would have
done to go elsewhere. But once in market he could not get out;
in the course of time he did away with vain regrets, and became
so much ham.
The second pig stayed home. Pathetic porker! He cut a
nine-thirty waiting for the car that never came.
He who got eight bids unquestionably accepted the worst of
the eight. These unworldly pigs are overwhelmed by numbers
and by the semblance of popularity. But he could always tell
his children, in later life, of the other seven bids.
History is kind to the fourth little pig. Perhaps he was a
crank and didn't want a bid. More probably, no one ever knew
whether or not he was bitterly disappointed.
And this little pig said "Boo-hoo-hoo" all the way home. Even
in infancy, when it was represented by my own pink tiny "tootsie,"
I felt indescribably sorry for that little pig.

JOHN SMITH ISN'T ALWAYS TO BE CONSIDERED
After all, the best of us will get our principles mixed occasionally. We see that our worthy contemporary, the Evening
Sun, laments the absence of "intellectual freedom" at the University of West Virginia. Now this wail, we believe, is a most
noble one, and one that should be wailed whenever such stupidity
as was exercised at West Virginia is demonstrated. On the other
hand, however, the president of the university offered an excuse
which could easily find validity in many of the underlying arguments of Evening Sun editorials.
President Trotter said that the reason why a certain pacifist was
not allowed to speak at West Virginia was that "this is a Statesupported institution and too much turmoil had been caused by
the invitation." Or, in other words, West Virginia is John.
Smith, taxpayer's college, and if John Smith doesn't want some
one to talk at his college, that some one isn't going to talk—that's
all there is to it!
The former principle, it seems to us, is.the more commendable
of the two; intellectual freedom is a higher ideal than a slim tax
rate. Or, perhaps, this is one occasion upon which John Smith
pays his money and then has nothing more to say about it!.

THE NAVY IS RIGHT
It seems pre-eminently ludicrous to us that Yale should bar
Bruce Caldwell from her football team because of participation
in two games during his freshman year at Brown, and expect
Princeton to do the same thing under similar circumstances, when
the United States Military Academy plays bona fide games with
all the leading colleges of the country with men in her line-up
playing their seventh year of college football. If Princeton or
Dartmouth were to use men who were playing their fourth year
of football, Yale should probably protest vehemently; nevertheless,
the Army game is one of the high spots of the Eli schedule every
year.
We cannot blame the Navy for kicking. Why should Navy
have to develop her material each year and go into the biggest
game of the season against men who had been picked on AllAmerican teams before members of the Navy team were out of
high school? It is true that "Biff" 'Jones, the Army coach,
strongly denies trying to convince star football players of the
pleasures and amenities of the great Army life, but it does seem
a little more than a coincidence that the bulwarks of the West
Point elevens for the past few years have been former stars at
other colleges.
The fault lies as much with the large colleges who comprise
the Army schedule as it does with the Army herself. If Yale
and Notre Dame and Bucknell would insist upon Army's barring
men who have already had one football career, Army would have
to fall into line. The Navy, acting alone, seems powerless to cause
any change. It would be, indeed, deplorable if one of the most
colorful annual football classics should be discontinued because
one of the teams insisted upon adhering to an eligibility code that
differed from that of every college in the country.

There is a delightful bit of verse, possessed of that brand of
inanity essential to the immortality of a nursery-rhyme, which—
perhaps because of the insidious influence of the recent red-hot
issue of the Black and Blue Jay—occurs to me whenever some
proud or disconsolate "brother" tells me how many men his fraternity "got." It is a rhyme which the less callous readers will,
in a spirit of unavowed sentiment, associate with that time when
their toes were as tender,as their souls:
This little pig went to market,
This little pig stayed home.
This little pig had roast beef,
This little pig had none.
This little pig said "boo-hoo-hoo!" all the way home.
Some time, when no one is watching, rehearse it—big toe, next
toe, etc. Then apply it to five freshmen, substituting a name—
of course—for each pig. Thus;
This little(?) went Beta,
This little (pain?) stayed home.
This little (lion) had eight bids,
This (poor mutt) had none.
And the last line may be repeated in its original form.
Why an essay on the mysteries of fraternity-rushing should
require all the equipment of a pastoral is an open question. However, the next simile—a worse one, I warn you, than the first—is
also of the barnyard variety. It is concerned with the mysteries
relevant to the separation of the sheep and the goats. Of course,
